title: The archer's paradox in slow motion

multiple-choice.question: What is the archer's paradox?

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why is blue so rare in nature?

multiple-choice.question: Why are blue animals relatively rare in nature?

options.label: B
options.text: Because blue light is not visible to many animals.

options.label: C
options.text: Because blue colors are not useful for communication or survival.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because blue pigments require a new type of chemistry that is difficult to evolve.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: Why some people don't have an inner monologue

multiple-choice.question: What is inner speech defined as in psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: The process of visualizing or picturing things in your head.

options.label: B
options.text: The narration inside your head, sometimes called inner speech.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to repeat information to yourself until you no longer need it.

options.label: D
options.text: The sensation of happiness or hunger.

multiple-choice.question: According to psychologists, what is the main content of inner speech?

options.label: A
options.text: Conversations about everyday life and events.

options.label: B
options.text: Negative things about ourselves, our negative emotions, or us trying to decide if we’re good enough.

options.label: C
options.text: Conversations with imaginary friends or people we know.

options.label: D
options.text: Conversations about solving problems and planning things out.

options.text: The motor theory.

options.label: B
options.text: The sensory theory.

options.label: C
options.text: The prediction theory.

options.label: D
options.text: The error correction theory.

multiple-choice.question: What is the dual-task paradigm used to study the effect of inner speech on problem solving?

options.label: A
options.text: A test that asks the person to solve a problem while doing something else.

options.label: B
options.text: A test that asks the person to solve a problem while remaining silent.

options.label: C
options.text: A test that asks the person to solve a problem while thinking about someone else’s experience and perspective.

options.label: D
options.text: A test that asks the person to solve a problem while visualizing the solution.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of inner speech in cognitive tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: It improves working memory by allowing people to repeat information to themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: It improves problem-solving skills by allowing people to talk themselves through the problem.

options.label: C
options.text: It improves emotional regulation by allowing people to manage their emotions more effectively.

options.label: D
options.text: It improves attention by allowing people to focus on the task at hand.

multiple-choice.question: B: The narration inside your head, sometimes called inner speech.
B: Negative things about ourselves, our negative emotions, or us trying to decide if we’re good enough.
D: The error correction theory.
A: A test that asks the person to solve a problem while doing something else.
B: It improves problem-solving skills by allowing people to talk themselves through the problem.

title: How to deal with rejection

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: The end of Roe v. Wade — and what comes next - Kathryn Kolbert

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is likely to happen to Roe v. Wade in the near future?

options.label: A
options.text: It will be upheld by the Supreme Court.

options.label: B
options.text: It will be overruled by the Supreme Court.

options.label: C
options.text: It will be modified by the Supreme Court.

options.label: D
options.text: It will be ignored by the Supreme Court.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the speaker believes that the Supreme Court will overrule Roe v. Wade?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the changing views of the American people.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the increasing conservatism of the courts.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the opposition from pro-choice groups.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the lack of support from the government.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main strategies that the speaker proposes to address the potential loss of reproductive freedoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Building a social justice movement and electing champions for choice.

options.label: B
options.text: Raising awareness about the issue and lobbying for change.

options.label: C
options.text: Focusing on state-level politics and local activism.

options.label: D
options.text: Engaging in non-violent protests and civil disobedience.

multiple-choice.question: What would be the potential consequences of the Supreme Court overruling Roe v. Wade?

options.label: A
options.text: Women would have greater access to abortion services.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of abortions would decrease.

options.label: C
options.text: Women would be forced to travel to other states for abortion services.

options.label: D
options.text: The issue of abortion would become less of a concern.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's proposal for a constitutional amendment to guarantee reproductive freedoms?

options.label: A
options.text: A constitutional amendment that would ban abortion in all 50 states.

options.label: B
options.text: A constitutional amendment that would guarantee the right to abortion.

options.label: C
options.text: A constitutional amendment that would establish a national standard for abortion.

options.label: D
options.text: A constitutional amendment that would eliminate the need for abortion.

title: 3 myths about racism that keep the US from progress - Candis Watts Smith

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one of the reasons why Americans often struggle to address racism?

options.label: A
options.text: Americans have a narrow definition of racism that only applies to the South.

options.label: B
options.text: Americans have an orientation toward progress that blinds them to the gap between where they are and where they could be.

options.label: C
options.text: Americans are not willing to make sacrifices to address racism.

options.label: D
options.text: Americans are not aware of the existence of racism.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions that young people, particularly white millennials, like diversity and appreciate it, but often don't live diverse lives. What does this suggest about their racial attitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that they are more open-minded and willing to engage with people from different racial backgrounds.

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that they are more racially conservative than older generations.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that they are not interested in addressing racial disparities.

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that they are unaware of the existence of racial disparities.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker argues that racism is not just a matter of individual attitudes, but also of systems, policies, and rules that marginalize certain groups. What is the implication of this argument?

options.label: A
options.text: That racism can only be addressed through individual attitudes and actions.

options.label: B
options.text: That racism is a complex issue that requires a multifaceted approach.

options.label: C
options.text: That racism is not a significant problem in American society.

options.label: D
options.text: That racism is only a problem in the South.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker suggests that one way to address racism is to have hard conversations with children about racism and its impact. What is the purpose of these conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: To teach children to be colorblind and ignore racial differences.

options.label: B
options.text: To protect children from a harsh racial reality.

options.label: C
options.text: To equip children to solve the problems of racism.

options.label: D
options.text: To make children feel guilty about racism.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker argues that living in a post-racist world is a possibility, but it requires a shared definition of racism and a commitment to becoming anti-racists. What is the implication of this argument?

options.label: A
options.text: That living in a post-racist world is impossible.

options.label: B
options.text: That living in a post-racist world is a utopian dream.

options.label: C
options.text: That living in a post-racist world requires a significant amount of effort and commitment.

options.label: D
options.text: That living in a post-racist world is not worth striving for.

title: Where do your online returns go? - Aparna Mehta

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of returned clothing ends up in the landfill every year?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 billion pounds

options.label: B
options.text: 4 billion pounds

options.label: C
options.text: 6 billion pounds

options.label: D
options.text: 7.5 billion pounds

options.label: A
options.text: $201 billion

options.label: B
options.text: $251 billion

options.label: C
options.text: $351 billion

options.label: D
options.text: $451 billion

options.label: A
options.text: "Green turn"

options.label: B
options.text: "Eco-return"

options.label: C
options.text: "Sustainable swap"

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the proposed incentive that Aparna suggests could encourage consumers to participate in the "green turn" process?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Cash back

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: Discounts

multiple-choice.question: If every adult in the US returned five fewer items this year, how many pounds of clothes could be kept out of the landfill?

options.label: A
options.text: 120 million pounds

options.label: B
options.text: 180 million pounds

options.label: C
options.text: 240 million pounds

options.label: D
options.text: 300 million pounds

title: The dark history of zombies - Christopher M. Moreman

multiple-choice.question: Where did the concept of zombies originate from?

options.label: A
options.text: Ancient Greece and Rome

options.label: B
options.text: Equatorial and Central Africa

options.label: C
options.text: The Caribbean island of Haiti and the Dominican Republic

options.label: D
options.text: The Americas

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the word "zombie" in Haitian culture?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents a powerful deity

options.label: B
options.text: It symbolizes a person's soul being captured and stored

options.label: C
options.text: It is a term used to describe a person who has been enslaved

options.label: D
options.text: It is a term used to describe a person who has been cursed

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the original concept of zombies and the modern concept?

options.label: A
options.text: The original concept was more violent, while the modern concept is more peaceful

options.label: B
options.text: The original concept was more spiritual, while the modern concept is more physical

options.label: C
options.text: The original concept was more about enslavement, while the modern concept is more about mindless violence

options.label: D
options.text: The original concept was more about supernatural powers, while the modern concept is more about science fiction

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the film "White Zombie" (1932) in the evolution of zombies in popular culture?

options.label: A
options.text: It introduced the concept of zombies to the Western world

options.label: B
options.text: It portrayed zombies as sympathetic characters

options.label: C
options.text: It perpetuated racist stereotypes about Haitian people

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first zombie film to feature a black protagonist

multiple-choice.question: What is a common theme in many modern zombie films and stories?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of family and community

options.label: B
options.text: The dangers of consumer culture

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of disaster preparedness

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of individualism and self-reliance

title: The dark history of the overthrow of Hawaii - Sydney Iaukea

multiple-choice.question: Who was arrested and imprisoned on January 16th, 1895?

options.label: A
options.text: King Kalākaua

options.label: B
options.text: Queen Lili’uokalani

options.label: C
options.text: A member of the "Committee of Safety"

options.label: D
options.text: A US Marine

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the Missionary Party's plot to annex Hawaii?

options.label: A
options.text: To expand the power of the ali'i

options.label: B
options.text: To bring Hawaii under US control

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a constitutional monarchy

options.label: D
options.text: To export sugar to the US tariff-free

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the document that Queen Lili’uokalani was forced to sign in exchange for the release of her supporters?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The Provisional Government Declaration

options.label: C
options.text: The Oath of Allegiance

options.label: D
options.text: The Relinquishment of the Throne

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Queen Lili’uokalani's visit to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists?

options.label: A
options.text: The Republic's annexation treaty was ratified

options.label: B
options.text: Congress halted the Republic's annexation treaty

options.label: C
options.text: The US declared Hawaii a sovereign kingdom

options.label: D
options.text: The Spanish-American War began

multiple-choice.question: What was Queen Lili’uokalani's ultimate goal, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To restore power to the ali'i

options.label: B
options.text: To establish a constitutional monarchy

options.label: C
options.text: To bring peace and annexation to Hawaii

options.label: D
options.text: To fight for Native Hawaiian rights and national liberation

title: The untapped genius that could change science for the better - Jedidah Isler

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the significance of occupying a position at an intersection?

options.label: A
options.text: It means being at the center of attention.

options.label: B
options.text: It means having the freedom to create from the indefiniteness of not-quite-here, not-quite-there.

options.label: C
options.text: It means being at the bottom of the social hierarchy.

options.label: D
options.text: It means being at the top of the social hierarchy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's personal experience with facing racialized gender bias in STEM?

options.label: A
options.text: She has never faced any bias and has always been welcomed in STEM.

options.label: B
options.text: She was mistaken for the janitorial staff by one of her classmates.

options.label: C
options.text: She was ostracized by her entire class and never experienced any bias.

options.label: D
options.text: She was not accepted into any STEM programs due to her appearance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the speaker's talk, according to her?

options.label: A
options.text: To encourage women to pursue careers in STEM, but only if they are white.

options.label: B
options.text: To say directly to every black, Latina, indigenous, First Nation or any other woman or girl who finds herself resting at the blessed intersection of race and gender that she can be anything she wants to be.

options.label: C
options.text: To highlight the difficulties faced by women in STEM, but only if they are women of color.

options.label: D
options.text: To discuss the importance of diversity and inclusion in STEM, but only for women.

multiple-choice.question: Who is Dr. Claudia Alexander, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: A white woman physicist who led the NASA side of the Rosetta mission.

options.label: B
options.text: A black woman plasma physicist who spearheaded the NASA side of the Rosetta mission.

options.label: C
options.text: A scientist who has no relation to NASA or the Rosetta mission.

options.label: D
options.text: A physicist who has no relation to the speaker or her story.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience about women of color in STEM?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not capable of contributing to the conversations in STEM.

options.label: B
options.text: They are uniquely positioned to contribute to and drive conversations in STEM in ways that are more inclusive of a wider variety of lived experience.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not necessary for the advancement of STEM.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only needed in certain areas of STEM, but not in others.

title: Can you outsmart the fallacy that divided a nation? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: Representative James Tallmage Jr. delivers a speech in which he calls slavery an "abomination" and a "monstrous scourge". What does he insist should be done to prevent the extension of slavery?

options.label: A
options.text: He believes the federal government should prohibit slavery in all new states.

options.label: B
options.text: He thinks the federal government should allow states to choose whether or not to allow slavery.

options.label: C
options.text: He insists that slavery shouldn't be allowed in Missouri or any new state.

options.label: D
options.text: He proposes a compromise between pro-slavery and anti-slavery views.

multiple-choice.question: Senator Thomas proposes a compromise that involves drawing a line through territories yet to become states, where slavery will be prohibited north of the line and allowed south of it. What is this compromise based on?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that both pro-slavery and anti-slavery views are equally valid.

options.label: B
options.text: The middle ground fallacy.

options.label: C
options.text: The concept of states' rights.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that slavery is morally indefensible.

multiple-choice.question: What is the middle ground fallacy, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that a compromise between two positions, one of which is morally indefensible, is also morally indefensible.

options.label: B
options.text: The concept that a compromise between two opposing views is always a good thing.

options.label: C
options.text: The notion that both sides in a debate have equal merit.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that a compromise can never lead to injustice.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument against the Missouri compromise?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is based on the concept of states' rights.

options.label: B
options.text: That it does not address the issue of slavery.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is based on the middle ground fallacy.

options.label: D
options.text: That it does not take into account the views of all people.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of Abraham Lincoln's promise not to interfere with slavery in states where it exists, but to prohibit its expansion into new territories and states?

options.label: A
options.text: A peaceful resolution to the issue of slavery.

options.label: B
options.text: A compromise between pro-slavery and anti-slavery views.

options.label: C
options.text: The outbreak of a Civil War over slavery.

options.label: D
options.text: The abolition of slavery in all states.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The creative space

options.label: C

options.label: B

title: An ode to envy - Parul Sehgal

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's personal experience with jealousy that they share at the beginning of the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: They were once a victim of jealousy, but the perpetrator was caught.

options.label: B
options.text: They were once jealous of a classmate's academic achievements.

options.label: C
options.text: They were once in a relationship where their partner was extremely jealous.

options.label: D
options.text: They have never experienced jealousy in their life.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the relationship between jealousy and the novel?

options.label: A
options.text: Jealousy is a common theme in novels, but it's not a central aspect of the genre.

options.label: B
options.text: The novel is a reflection of jealousy, but it's not a direct representation.

options.label: C
options.text: The novel is a way to explore and understand jealousy in a deeper way.

options.label: D
options.text: The novel is a way to avoid dealing with jealousy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's interpretation of Proust's work in relation to jealousy?

options.label: A
options.text: Proust's work is a way to avoid dealing with jealousy.

options.label: B
options.text: Proust's work is a way to romanticize jealousy.

options.label: C
options.text: Proust's work is a way to explore and understand jealousy in a deeper way.

options.label: D
options.text: Proust's work is a way to dismiss jealousy as a trivial emotion.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the relationship between jealousy and creativity?

options.label: A
options.text: Jealousy is a hindrance to creativity.

options.label: B
options.text: Jealousy is a source of inspiration for creativity.

options.label: C
options.text: Jealousy is a neutral aspect of creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: Jealousy is a way to avoid dealing with creativity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for dealing with jealousy?

options.label: A
options.text: We should try to avoid jealousy altogether.

options.label: B
options.text: We should try to understand and explore jealousy in a deeper way.

options.label: C
options.text: We should try to align ourselves with the excellence of others.

options.label: D
options.text: We should try to resent the excellence of others.

title: Can stereotypes ever be good? - Sheila Marie Orfano and Densho

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the stereotype that portrays Asian students as industrious, intelligent, and gentle?

options.label: A
options.text: Model minority stereotype

options.label: B
options.text: Problem minority stereotype

options.label: C
options.text: Racial hierarchy stereotype

options.label: D
options.text: Compliant minority stereotype

multiple-choice.question: Why did the US government try to "Americanize" incarcerated Japanese Americans during World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: To prepare them for life in prison

options.label: B
options.text: To transform their public perception from suspected traitors to an American success story

options.label: C
options.text: To teach them English language classes

options.label: D
options.text: To punish them for their actions

multiple-choice.question: What is the psychological phenomenon known as that can lead to poor performance among individuals who are under pressure to live up to a positive stereotype?

options.label: A
options.text: Stereotype threat

options.label: B
options.text: Racial hierarchy threat

options.label: C
options.text: Compliant minority threat

options.label: D
options.text: Model minority threat

multiple-choice.question: How does the model minority stereotype impact social programs catering to Asian communities?

options.label: A
options.text: They are frequently overlooked or cut because they're assumed to need more support

options.label: B
options.text: They are frequently overlooked or cut because they're assumed to need less support

options.label: C
options.text: They are frequently increased because they're assumed to need more support

options.label: D
options.text: They are frequently increased because they're assumed to need less support

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of reducing a group of people to a one-dimensional image created by a racial stereotype?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a deeper understanding of the group's history, struggles, and triumphs

options.label: B
options.text: It hinders our ability to understand the history, struggles, and triumphs of the individuals within that group

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on our understanding of the group

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to a greater sense of unity among the group members
